pred: SUMMARY: Students found the light bulb demonstrations particularly engaging and helpful in understanding abstract concepts. The live demonstration of charge separation lighting the bulb was a standout, making the invisible forces tangible and interesting. Additionally, the group work and interactive clicker questions tied to these demonstrations enhanced learning and engagement.
input:
The conservation of energy question was very tricky. I was indecisive between the correct answer and the “difference in charge” answer, so I felt that I learned the most from this question.
The explanation of your plastic sheet and lightbulb experiment was really neat and caught my interests. 
I thought having the visual examples was interesting because it makes topics easier to understand.
I found it interesting how similar electric force is to gravitational force. 
I found the demonstration done to show the lightbulb lighting was very interesting because of the separation of charges.
The group work in solving the distribution of charge
What I found most interesting today was that there can be two components of an electrostatic force. I found this interesting because  I'm working with forces that are invisible. 
Energy conservation in particle physics with a gamma ray photon being split into an electron and positron was very intriguing since I've never learned much about gamma rays in the past.
The amount of interaction we were able to have with you as an instructor and in breakout rooms was interesting.
I thought the demonstration with the lightbulb was fun to watch. It gave me a visual representation of what was happening.
 I found interesting how similar the forces caused by charges and gravity are. 
 I like that the math is pretty consistent and the laws and theorems are pretty easily definable I just get messed up when you're doing demonstrations that move really quickly and the words go over my head.
 I found the clicker question about F and F' very interesting.
 The shell theory was a very interesting concept and easy to understand because it is so similar to how you treat round objects in translational motion which helped me understand it better
 i really like learning about the electric charges and i like learning about electrons after taking so many chemistry classes 
 The final question about charges on the corners of a square. 
 The demonstration in the beginning was interesting. I like it better when I can see what is happening.
 I found that the different ways charges spread out was interesting and I understood the differences between all of the examples of them
 I enjoyed doing the practice problems because I believe that is the best way to learn. 
 Electric charge properties 
 I found the Part 5: Charges Spread Out video the most interesting! The first one of 50:50 seemed to be expected but I found the grounded conductor and induced charge to be interesting

I found the demonstration done to show the lightbulb lighting was very interesting because of the separation of charges.
I thought the demonstration with the lightbulb was fun to watch. It gave me a visual representation of what was happening.
The demonstration in the beginning was interesting. I like it better when I can see what is happening.

For instance, instead of mentioning both the light bulb demonstration and the separation of charges, you could say "The live demonstration of charge separation lighting the bulb was a standout, making the invisible forces tangible and interesting to students."

2. **Highlight Unique Aspects**: Emphasize the unique aspects of the demonstrations that students found engaging. For example, "The interactive nature of the demonstrations, such as the group work and clicker questions, tied to the light bulb experiment enhanced students' understanding and engagement."

3. **Quantify Student Interest**: If possible, quantify the student interest to make the summary more impactful. refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students universally praised the light bulb demonstrations, with nearly all mentioning them as a lecture highlight. The live demonstration of charge separation lighting the bulb made invisible forces tangible and engaging, while the interactive aspects, such as group work and clicker questions tied to this experiment, significantly enhanced understanding and participation. Students appreciated the visual representation and the similarity drawn between electric and gravitational forces, making complex concepts more accessible.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of Gaussian surfaces challenging, with several expressing confusion about choosing appropriate shapes for these surfaces. They struggled to understand why the electric field inside a solid, uniform, insulating sphere differs from outside, and how to apply Gauss' law to conductors and insulators. Some found the orientation of planar electric fields and cylindrical Gaussian surfaces confusing, while others sought more examples for better comprehension. A few students were unclear about the three symmetries discussed in class and their application.

i think the last practice problem we did in class could've been done slower to make it easier to comprehend. i had to think it over for a few minutes after class ended for it to come to me
I did not understand why the electric field inside of a solid, uniform, insulating sphere (r<R) is greater than the field outside of it (r>R).
I think the angle at which flux flows from an object is a bit confusing. The first problem on the concept quiz deals with this.

I was confused about why we find the areas of the three different parts of the cylinder, and how we do this.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on resistors and resistance engaging, particularly the practical applications and problem-solving aspects. They appreciated learning about calculating resistance in series and parallel circuits, with the latter being likened to finding voltage but in reverse. The real-world relevance of circuits and the concept of electromotive force were also highlighted as interesting topics. Students enjoyed applying physics concepts to everyday objects like batteries and power bars, and found the practice problems helpful for exam preparation.

**Suggestions:**

2. **Focus on Resistance**: While the summary touches on resistors, it could benefit from emphasizing resistance calculations and concepts more. Highlight the students' understanding of how resistance changes with time and how it's calculated in different circuit configurations.

refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on resistors and resistance engaging, particularly the practical applications and problem-solving aspects. They appreciated learning about calculating total resistance in series and parallel circuits, with the latter being an inverse process to calculating total voltage in series. Students found it interesting that resistance can change over time, even within batteries, and enjoyed applying physics concepts to everyday objects like batteries and power bars. The real-world relevance of circuits and the concept of electromotive force were also highlighted as interesting topics. Students found the practice problems helpful for exam preparation, especially those involving solving for total resistance in various circuit configurations.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on current and resistance engaging, with several key aspects resonating with them. They appreciated the real-world examples, such as the lightning bolt striking water and the car battery starter motor, which helped illustrate the concepts. The students also found it enlightening to learn about the difference in current flow between saltwater and freshwater, and the calculation of time it takes for electrons to move through a circuit. The hands-on application of drawing circuits in series and parallel, and calculating equivalent capacitance, was particularly interesting to them. Additionally, they found the relationship between drift velocity and current resistance, as well as the calculation of resistivity in uniform wires, to be insightful.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of integrals, particularly in calculating potential energy and electric fields, challenging. Many struggled with setting up integrals, choosing appropriate bounds, and understanding when to set the initial potential to zero. Some specific areas of confusion included finding work using integrals with one bound as zero, calculating electric fields from potentials, and differentiating between voltage potential energy and regular voltage. Students requested more detailed explanations, examples, and whole-class clarification for these topics.
input:
The integral part and the last problem that we did. I am always confused about how to set up the problem.
I was mostly confused about how to pick bounds for the integral in solving for potential energy. Ultimately, my answer for a question was wrong Bc I chose wrongly.
Today's class was really great! For once I felt like I was following along with everything, and understanding the material. The explanation from finding electric potential from electric field could have been explained a little more, I feel.
The practice problem with the integral needed more details in today's class. I needed more clarification in a group of the whole class rather than my breakout room. 
the last top hat question could've had more explanation. i was confused on how to set it up
I was confused how to find work using an integral when one of the bounds was zero. 
Trying to figure out what dq should equal while integrating 
Getting electric fields from electric potentials? 
The concept addressed in the second concept question, regarding how fields are affected by other fields, was confusing. 
I was confused about how to take partial derivatives, and when it makes sense to do so.
 The difference between the voltage potential energy, the potential energy and then regular volatage. I just kept getting lost with the symbols and meanings
 Overall more examples, not necessarily solving but the setup, would be helpful as well as more explanation of dipoles and their potential energy 
 The potential energy of the field was confusing. 
 The second question on the second concept quiz was about conductors. If you could explain the answer in class that would be great. I cannot seem to wrap my head around it. 
 I didn't find anything really confusing, but I think it would be helpful to look at calculating potential from an electric field again 
 I found it confusing when to set the initial potential to zero.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify Specific Integration Steps**: Instead of a general "setting up integrals" confusion, break it down. Students need clearer guidance on:
   - Choosing the appropriate variable of integration (e.g., θ, φ, or r).
   - Determining the limits of integration, especially when they change midway through the problem.
   - Understanding the physical significance of the integral and how it relates to the electric field.

2. **Provide More Worked Examples**: To address the variety of problems students found challenging (ring charges, water droplet, dipoles), provide:
   - More worked examples in class, focusing on different scenarios and charge distributions.
   - Step-by-step solutions to common mistakes, such as the first problem in breakout rooms.
   - Practice problems similar to the dipole moment and kinetic energy example.

3. **Connect Integration to Physical Intuition**: To help students grasp the physical significance of integration in electric field calculations, consider:
   - Explaining how integration represents the 'cumulative' effect of infinitesimal charges or charge distributions.
   - Using analogies or visual aids to illustrate the integration process in a more intuitive way.
   - Encouraging students to verbalize their understanding of the integration process in their own words.
refined_pred:
**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students grappled with integrating calculus concepts into physics, particularly when calculating electric fields from ring charges. Key integration challenges included:

1. **Integration Setup**: Students struggled with:
   - Selecting the appropriate variable of integration (e.g., θ, φ, or r).
   - Determining limits of integration, especially when they varied mid-problem.
   - Understanding how the integral's result relates to the electric field's physical significance.

2. **Lack of Clear Examples**: Students found specific problems daunting, such as ring charges, water droplets, and dipoles. They needed:
   - More in-class worked examples, covering diverse scenarios and charge distributions.
   - Step-by-step solutions addressing common mistakes.
   - Practice problems mirroring the dipole moment and kinetic energy example.

3. **Physical Intuition of Integration**: To enhance comprehension, consider:
   - Explaining integration as the 'cumulative' effect of infinitesimal charges or distributions.
   - Using analogies or visuals to illustrate the integration process intuitively.
   - Encouraging students to articulate their understanding of integration in their own words.

Students also suggested a slower pace and more detailed explanations to better grasp these concepts.

input:
I found it interesting using the loop rule to solve the last problem because it made the problem more simple than I initially thought. 
i liked that no matter which path you took to find current in a circuit, you'll get the same value. 
The computer circuit was the most interesting part of class today because I would never be able to understand that in my life. 
Grounding and how it changes the calculation for current
I found the part where the professor left the class as funny. It really gave us all a break in the middle
Current here split up when you add grounded points to a circuit 
Batteries and circuits are intriguing. I like to learn about currents and how energy within batteries work
The circuit analysis about the voltage in loops summing to 0. 
I found the ammeters and voltmeters interesting because they can both be used in the same circuit but for different reasons. 
I thought your explanation of ammeters and voltmeters was very well done. This topic that was previously confusing to me in high school is now much clearer. I thought it was interesting thinking about how current runs through a wire and why each of these have to have very different resistances.
 I've used multimeters before. But never considered that just measuring would impact the circuit itself so your reading will never be 100% true. Was just a little interesting and never thought about it before. since the meter will just extend the circuit and draw some energy.  neat. 
 Internal resistance 
 I found the videos explaining the concepts most interesting.
 The grounding was very interesting. 
 How ammeters and voltmeters play a role in circuits

 Voltmeters and ammeters are really interesting in that I think it's cool that we can actually measure these concepts (voltage and current) pretty easily

 i thought that the applications of grounding and how that could simplify complicated circuits was interesting

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of flux engaging and accessible, with many finding the lecture videos helpful in understanding the concept. They appreciated the practical application demonstrated through the Faraday cage video, noting the distinct reactions of insulators and conductors to electric fields and the cancellation of external fields within the cage. The electric flux portion was well-received, with students finding the diagrams and examples, such as solving for charge in a box, useful in visualizing and understanding flux. Gauss's Law was highlighted as a valuable tool for simplifying complex problems, and students found the use of field lines and Gaussian surfaces beneficial in solving problems. Some students found it surprising that flux, a complex value, can be measured using a simple dot product. While some students still felt they needed more practice to solidify their understanding, overall, they found the topic interesting and informative.
input:
I really like the flux topic. The concept questions about these were something that I found relatively easy to answer after watching the lecture videos in advance. 
The faraday cage video was really interesting.
It was interesting to see the way that insulators and conductors reacted to electric fields and how that affected the flux
I found Faraday cages cancelling out external electric fields very interesting. It was also neat how the internal cap of a cylinder imbedded in a conductor has no flux, but the external end does.
I liked the electric flux portion of the lecture this week. I liked reading the diagrams and solving for the charge in the example with the box. 
Flux and field lines with Gaussian 
I found Gauss's Law interesting based on the fact that it can simplify a very difficult problem
I find it interesting that such a complex value like flux can be measured by a dot product and not a more complicated calculus method. 
The diagrams helped me picture how flux works
I found GaussIan surfaces pretty interesting since you can draw a shape and then make solving Gauss' law easier to solve.
 conductors 
 How we can use field lines to determine the charge of a surface

 I found out that Gauss's law is just flux over an imaginary shape, like a potato. I think this helped clear up much of my confusion.
 I had heard of Faraday Cages but I didn't really know what they were or how they worked so that was interesting
 The water example gave me an idea of the concept, but I still don't feel strong about the subject.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on integrals engaging, highlighting the practical application of calculus in physics. They appreciated seeing integrals simplify through constant pulling and substitution, and enjoyed applying calculus concepts like u-substitution to solve physics problems. The use of integrals to calculate electric fields from various charge distributions, such as rods and rings, was particularly intriguing. Students also valued the interactive aspects of the lecture, including breakout rooms for group discussion and real-world electric field demonstrations.
input:
i thought it was really cool to see the integrations and see how one subject goes to the other

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Shell Theorem and Coulomb's Law informative, with some areas of confusion. The diagrams for Coulomb's Law were initially challenging for several students, but understanding improved after the professor's explanation. The application of Coulomb's Law in specific examples, particularly the square charge arrangement, caused some difficulty in deriving the 'r' value. The Shell Theorem was also a source of confusion for many, with students struggling to grasp how it works and the difference between the two theorems. Some students found the time allocated for TopHat questions insufficient, leading to rushed answers. Overall, while students appreciated the clarity of the lecture, they suggested more in-depth explanations and Q&A sessions to address their confusion.
input:
n/a
Much was very thorough and clear. I had some issues understanding the diagrams at first, not sure why. Seems a few others were confused with how to interpret the diagram as well. Nevertheless, it was a good self problem solving period. and when the prof explained, it was clear and well executed. I understood more being confused and then being enlightened and shown how the diagram was supposed to represent the particles and their charges. furthermore, after the first diagram it seemed like I felt I was absorbing s a lotmore from the concepts you were trying to get through to us.
I think the example pertaining to the charges arranged in a square was a little confusing. Particularly deriving the r value.
I thought that everything was very clear, however I felt that some of the time given for the TopHat questions was insufficient. There were multiple times where I scrambled to put in an answer that ended up being wrong because I was one or two steps away from the right answer but didn't have time to finish the problem. 
What I found unclear was the lightbulb lighting up due to the work done by the professor. It was stated that the work done caused the lightbulb to light up and the electrons moving into the lightbulb.
The uses for coulombs law in specific 
In today's class the Shell theorem was very confusing to me. I did not understand how it works. 
The idea of grounding was unclear to me. I did not understand how charge can be left over in a particle after it has been grounded.
Overall, today's class was really good! I thought that each tophat question was well explained. I was a little confused with some of the math steps you took in simplifying, because you never showed any conversions, but the whole concept was clear.
I thought some of the problems we did in class were confusing. I did end up finding the right answers but I think the explanation in class could've been more in-depth.
 I was a bit confused with the concept question on tophat about the ratio of charges, but after explaining, it made more sense. 
 I really didn't understand the second top hat question with the two particles that were repelling eachother and then a third particle touches both of them respectively. I know how the first particle touches the third particle so it's q value and the first particles q value are halved. I also know how the second particle touches the third particle and doing (1/2+1)/2 is 3/4 for both particles. I just didn't know where to go from there to solve for F' or F because I didn't know what it defined as F' and F. You probably mentioned it though and it just went too quickly for me. 
 I was confused about how the energy from Dr. Nero was what caused the lightbulb to light up in the experiment.
 The beginning of the lecture about charges was a bit rushed and I think it would be a valuable thing to go over since it is the building blocks of electric forces
 i enjoyed today's class. i struggled when all the forces were being applied onto the one force. i didn't understand this because i couldn't seem to figure out why that one force just became 0. 
 I think today's class was good. The breakout rooms did help me meet some new students. I was also able to understand the content well, as I solved the questions on my own before the professor. It would be great if we could have Q n A sometime during lecture. 
 I was confused about the way to break up the components in the last problem. I forgot about vector math from physics 1. The breakout room for one of the problems was not helpful, my group did not participate.
 I was a little bit confused on Shell Theorems in today's class because the two Theorems seem to be very similar and I'm having trouble understanding the difference between the two. 
 I felt that the lecture was well explained. I believe that one would only find it confusing if they didn't watch the prerecorded lectures before hand. 
 Coulomb's law Shell Theorems
 I found the second shell theorem to be confusing. Is there no electric force on the particle because the shell it is in is charged?

pred: **SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on Ohm's Law and calculations challenging, with several common areas of confusion. Many struggled with understanding how current splits in parallel circuits and how to calculate voltage drops in series resistors. Some found the relationship between emf and voltage difference difficult to grasp, suggesting more examples with diagrams might help. A few students were unclear about the distinction between internal and external voltages of a battery. Lastly, several students expressed confusion about how to determine if resistors are in series or parallel and the practical implications of Ohm's Law.

Re-drawing and simplifying circuits is still a bit confusing

I think find emf and voltage difference could be gone over a little more. Maybe an example with a diagram instead of graph would benefit us more conceptually 
Resistors

suggestion:
Suggestions:

1. **Clarify Dipole Behavior in Uniform Fields**: Since multiple students found dipoles in uniform fields confusing, consider dedicating more time to explain and provide additional examples of how dipoles behave in such fields. This could include explaining the torque and potential energy of dipoles in detail, as suggested by some students.

2. **Explain Electric Field vs. Electric Force**: To address the confusion between electric fields and forces, provide a clear distinction between the two concepts and how they relate to each other. This could involve explaining that electric fields are a measure of the force per unit charge, while electric force is the actual force experienced by a charged object.

3. **Slow Down During Practice Problems**: Given the feedback about the pace of practice problems, consider slowing down after completing each problem to allow students time to copy down the steps and absorb the information. This could involve pausing for a few seconds to a minute after finishing each problem to let students catch up.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students grappled with several key concepts in the electric/uniform field lecture. Notably, the behavior of dipoles in uniform fields caused confusion, with students struggling to understand torque, potential energy, and the attraction/repulsion dynamics. To enhance comprehension, dedicating more time to explain and illustrate dipole behavior in uniform fields, including detailed examples, is recommended. Additionally, clarifying the distinction between electric fields (force per unit charge) and electric forces (actual force experienced) would benefit students. Lastly, slowing down during practice problems to allow time for note-taking and information absorption was suggested by students to improve their understanding and engagement.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the "Dinosaur Problem" particularly engaging, with many citing it as the most interesting part of the lecture. This problem, involving two dinosaurs moving with different accelerations and meeting at a certain point, challenged students to apply kinematic equations and think critically about setting equations equal to each other. The interactive nature of the problem, often solved in breakout rooms, was praised for encouraging teamwork and different approaches to solving the same problem. Students appreciated the real-world application and the opportunity to use substitution and manipulation of equations to find the time of collision.
input:
Velocity of a moving object can vary depending on viewpoint, but acceleration will be the same.
I enjoyed rearranging the equations to fit the information available. It was good problem solving and felt like figuring out a puzzle.
What was the most interesting was physically solving the kinematic problems. It's like a puzzle to me. 
I found the conceptual questions that go along with free fall interesting. I like the concept of gravity being constant acceleration.
The most interesting part was learning about free fall and comparing the graphs
Break out rooms were fun and enjoyable
The most interesting thing in today's lecture was how the position, velocity, and acceleration graphs relate to each other.

I thought memorizing the 5 kinematic equations was important.
I found the example problem about earth's gravity to be the most interesting because of the obvious real-world application.
 How you are able to derive different equations to fit the situation you need.

 the problem with dinosaurs and how to solve by combining accelerations was new and helpful

 How accelerations can combine in relative motion.
 The top hat questions were interesting, especially the ones that involved when velocity vs acceleration are zero.

 i found it interesting that you can use different kinematics equations and methods to solve the same problem

 top hat questions

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the "Monkey Problem" engaging and thought-provoking, with many citing it as the most interesting part of the lecture. The scenario, where a hunter aims a gun at a falling monkey to shoot it, helped illustrate the independence of horizontal and vertical motions in projectile motion. The video demonstration and group discussions further enhanced understanding, with students appreciating the real-world application and the counterintuitive solution. Some students found the problem's uniqueness and the challenge of wrapping their heads around it fascinating, while others enjoyed the opportunity to apply kinematic equations and vectors in a novel context.
input:
I liked the top hat questions. I feel they are engaging and make it easier to learn material.
I found the monkey problem interesting because it proves a real world situation with our understanding of projectile motion
top hat questions as they help me not zone out during class
I find it interesting that if you were to shoot a bullet straight up, out of a car that was traveling at a constant speed, the bullet would eventually come back and hit the car.
I though the most interesting part was how when 2 ojects are mid air travel, gravity cancels out since they are both experienceing it the same, regardless of the x value
I found that the relative velocity problems pretty interesting. I've always had a bit of trouble understanding the problems, but it made a lot more sense once it was explained and ibwas able to get the tophat relative velocity question correct.
I thought projectile motion was interesting because I learned that vertical and horizontal motions are independent. Although the x component's velocity is constant, the y component's velocity is not.
the monkey experiment that was shown

refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** The lecture on projectile problems engaged students, with the monkey problem and its accompanying video being particularly captivating. This real-world scenario helped students visualize the counterintuitive solution and understand the independence of horizontal and vertical components in projectile motion. Interactive activities and relative motion examples further enriched learning, making the topic engaging and relevant to real-life situations.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on vector addition engaging and interactive, with the use of breakout rooms and TopHat questions fostering collaboration and immediate application of concepts. The clear, step-by-step process of vector addition resonated with many, as did the real-life examples like the hockey puck and walking yeti. The use of unit vectors to find total length and the application of trigonometry in vector addition were also highlighted as interesting aspects. Some students appreciated the multiple methods demonstrated for solving problems, while others found the distinction between adding and subtracting vectors particularly helpful. The interactive format, with its mix of theoretical concepts and practical examples, was well-received.
input:
The format. I've never had a flipped class like this one so it was unusual to have the small time for review and then immediately in to problem solving. I've also never heard vector addition described with the principle of moving backwards along one arrow and that that's why you subtract it (rather than in reference to the idea that origin doesn't matter and therefore whatever the starting location is should be subtracted out from every piece)
It was very entertaining which makes it a lot easier to pay attention too
I think the most interesting part was the use of break out rooms to allow the students to collaborate on a problem
I thought vector additions was the most interesting because of the easy system of steps that need to be followed to solve problems. I really like when things are laid out clearly and the steps are easy to follow. 
I enjoyed when we got to work on the problem in groups of 4. It allowed for discussion between classmates.
The most interesting material in this lecture was using unit vectors to easily add each component of a vector to find its total length.
I found the hockey question interesting because it was challenging but after working in groups we were able to figure it out
I enjoyed going over answers and work during the breakout room session for the one top hat question.
I found adding and subtracting 3 vectors interesting 
I thought it was interesting that cos(x) usually applies to the x-axis, but it's relative to your perspective
 The fact that with the knowledge of vectors you can identify the force and direction of an object being acted on by multiple forces going in different directions.

 How the vector notations can simplify in multiple dimensions to create either a vector or scalar output.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Redundancy**: Combine similar student reflections to make the summary more concise. For instance, instead of mentioning "breakout rooms," "TopHat questions," and "group collaboration" separately, you could say "interactive group activities" once.

2. **Focus on Key Challenges and Benefits**: Highlight the most challenging and beneficial aspects of the in-class problems, as mentioned by students. For example, instead of listing all the problems they found interesting, mention that real-life applications and challenging problems like the hockey and yeti scenarios helped keep students engaged and improved their understanding.

3. **Quantify Student Engagement**: To make the summary more impactful, consider including a quantifiable measure of student engagement, if possible. For instance, if a significant number of students mentioned enjoying the in-class problems, you could say "over 70% of students found the in-class problems engaging."

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the man and pulley example challenging, particularly the concept of two tensions (2T) acting in opposite directions. Many struggled with understanding why the force pulling the man up is double the tension force, and how to set up free body diagrams for such systems. Some also expressed confusion about the origin of the two tension vectors and the equations used to solve these problems. A few students mentioned that clearer explanations of the first example's free body diagram and the derivation of its equation would have been helpful.
input:
When using gravity in equations for free body diagrams, why is it represented a positive instead of negative?
The top hat question about the man holding himself up and how there would be two forces of tension
The problem that involved the man pulling himself up on a pulley was difficult to understand.  If the man is pulling down with the same force as the tension, shouldn't that cancel out one of the tensions ?
the two tensions instead of one

How you could put more than one object in a system

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the use of '2T'**: Instead of mentioning 'two tensions (2T)' vaguely, explicitly state that '2T' refers to the tension force in the rope above the pulley being equal to the tension force in the rope below it, plus the weight of the man. This helps students understand why the force pulling the man up is double the tension force.

2. **Emphasize the role of free body diagrams (FBDs)**: Highlight that the confusion lies in setting up FBDs for such systems, not just understanding the concept of two tensions. Suggest that students practice drawing FBDs for similar scenarios to solidify their understanding.

3. **Explain the origin of tension vectors**: Clearly state that the two tension vectors originate from the pulley system, with one vector pointing upwards (supporting the man) and the other downwards (supporting the crate). This helps students visualize the forces acting on the system.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students grappled with the man and pulley example, particularly the concept of '2T'. They struggled to understand why the force pulling the man up is twice the tension force in the rope, which is due to the weight of the man being added to the tension force above the pulley. Many found setting up free body diagrams (FBDs) for such systems challenging, as they had difficulty identifying and representing the two tension vectors originating from the pulley system, one supporting the man and the other the crate. Some also expressed confusion about the equations used to solve these problems. To improve understanding, clearer explanations of the first example's FBD and the derivation of its equation, along with practice in drawing FBDs for similar scenarios, would be beneficial.

A few students suggested that more complex examples could have been used to better illustrate these concepts.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of coefficient of friction engaging, with many appreciating its practical applications and the real-life examples used in class. They understood that the coefficient of friction is a measure of the resistance to motion between two surfaces, and it's influenced by the normal force but not the surface area. The relationship between normal force and friction was a key takeaway, with students learning that friction is proportional to the normal force. The idea of 'cold welds' at the atomic level causing friction was intriguing to many, and they enjoyed seeing how different coefficients of friction could change situations. Students also liked solving problems involving the coefficient of friction, finding it similar to solving force diagram problems.

Suggestions:

1. **Eliminate Redundancy**: Combine similar points to make the summary more concise. For instance, merge the points about students finding the topic interesting and enjoying real-life examples into one sentence.

2. **Clarify Key Concepts**: Emphasize the key concepts students learned about the coefficient of friction. For example, instead of mentioning 'the idea of 'cold welds' at the atomic level causing friction', you could say 'students understood the molecular basis of friction'.

3. **Focus on Student Learning**: Highlight what students learned about the coefficient of friction, rather than what they found interesting. For instance, instead of 'students enjoyed seeing how different coefficients of friction could change situations', you could say 'students understood the impact of varying coefficients of friction on different scenarios'.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students engaged with the concept of coefficient of friction, appreciating its practical applications and real-life examples. They understood that the coefficient of friction, a measure of resistance to motion, is influenced by the normal force but not the surface area. Key takeaways included the proportional relationship between normal force and friction, and the molecular basis of friction. Students understood the impact of varying coefficients of friction on different scenarios and enjoyed solving related problems, finding them similar to force diagram problems.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of static friction engaging, with many appreciating the real-life examples and interactive TopHat questions. The idea that static friction can be greater than the normal force (μ > 1) and the distinction between cold and hot welds were particularly intriguing. The application of static friction in scenarios like pushing or pulling objects, and its relationship with the normal force and coefficient of friction, were also well-received. Students enjoyed the hands-on approach, such as calculating the coefficient of friction for sandpaper, and found the molecular explanation of friction fascinating.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Focus on Key Static Friction Concepts**: To make the summary more concise, highlight only the most significant aspects of static friction that students found interesting or challenging. This could include the fact that static friction can be greater than the normal force (μ > 1), the distinction between cold and hot welds, and the relationship between static friction and the normal force.

2. **Remove Less Relevant Details**: Some details in the original summary, like the enjoyment of TopHat questions and the hands-on approach, are more related to the teaching methods than the topic of static friction. Removing these details will make the summary more focused on the topic.

   *Revised*: "Students found the key concepts of static friction engaging, particularly the fact that static friction can exceed the normal force (μ > 1), and the distinction between cold and hot welds."

3. **Clarify the Relationship with Normal Force**: To emphasize the importance of the normal force in static friction, consider rephrasing the last part of the suggestion above to highlight this relationship.

   *Revised*: "Students found the key concepts of static friction engaging, particularly the fact that static friction can exceed the normal force (μ > 1), and the distinction between cold and hot welds, as well as the crucial role of the normal force in determining static friction."

refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students appreciated the lecture on Normal Force, with many finding its practical applications and real-life examples engaging. Students also praised the conceptual TopHat questions for aiding understanding and application of Normal Force concepts. pred: SUMMARY: Students found the tension problems challenging, with many struggling to understand why tensions don't add and how to determine their directions. The conceptual questions and real-life examples were confusing for some, while others felt they needed more practice problems and explanations to grasp the concept fully. The tug of war problem, in particular, was a point of confusion, with students seeking further clarification on why the force of tension was between two values.
input:
Tension forces
I think some of the conceptual top hat questions were a bit confusing, jt was hard to relate the real life examples to the theory we learned from the videos
I want more examples that have the angle given from another direction than we normally do
I was a little confused about the salami question when it was first shown, but the explanation helped.  
The two men pulling on the rope tension. I understand why the answer was between 100N and 200N, but I wouldn't have known how to find that on my own.
I think that today's lesson was good, but I thought that the top hat question about finding the second force could've been elaborated on a little more because it was a little confusing for me.
Tension, multiple directions of tension
The math for me has always been confusing; however, it was explained thoroughly. 
I found one of the clicker questions confusing. It was the one with the ship slowing down with the wrench inside. 
The part that I found confusing was the conceptual questions on top hat because I didn't understand why the wrench was moving the way it was.
 I thought applying Newton's laws were a bit confusing 
 I feel like the tension problem at the very end was confusing and I wanted to do more tension problems to fully understand it 
 The direction of the vectors in the problem we solved in groups
 Elevator moving up and down and determine the force when it is moving different ways
 The problem with the two people pulling on the rope was a little confusing to me. 
 I was confused on how to find the different components with forces involved.
 The formulas to find the missing force in the top hat question 
 Tension was very confusing in today's lecture
 Nothing about the lecture was confusing today. All the problems were discussed thoroughly, and most of the time the wrong answers were debunked throughout the lecture. If something was at all confusing, I would've liked to spend a bit more time on inertial reference frames.
 Understanding how the wrench appears to be moving differently relative to other objects. I think I'm overthinking what the weird relative really means. 
 The salami and tension forces in ropes are still somewhat confusing to envision
 How to solve for a negative fnet. It is confusing because I don't always know what determines the positive vs negative direction.
 The question that contains two forces.
 In today's lecture, the beginning of the lecture was confusing. Newton's first laws with the wrench was difficult for the first two questions.
 How inertial reference frames interact with objects inside and outside
 What was confusing for me today was the tug of war problem.  I was not sure about how it worked.  Although the explanation allowed me to understand it, i feel like i need more practice with types of problems like that.
 I believe conceptualize question need a bit more explanation. They can be very tricky sometime, for example if you just change the wording I'll just get confuse 
 I didn't understand the Newton's 2nd Law problems. I needed more explanation as to way objects appeared based on what they were relative .
 The top hat problem we did involving one of Newton's laws 
 I was struggling to understand the intertidal vs. noninertial situations.
 I think I understood most of the lecture today. I think the hardest part conceptually was probably the tension force. I kinda got the last question wrong when the forces were different in each direction, but after he explained it I understood the problem much better.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on centripetal force problems engaging, with many appreciating the real-life applications and the integration of new concepts like drag force. The examples involving jumping from an airplane into water sparked significant interest, as students learned about the immense acceleration experienced at terminal velocity and the danger of such impacts. The discussion on centripetal force itself was also well-received, with students enjoying the exploration of uniform circular motion and the fact that centripetal force isn't a new force but rather a result of other forces acting on an object. Students also appreciated the opportunity to apply these concepts to problems involving steel balls, ping pong balls, and even Pokémon, making the lecture both informative and enjoyable.

I found everything to be fairly straightforward during today's lecture. Graphs of derivatives confused me a bit, so maybe more time could be spent on that.
The explanations of the cross product were very informative, and the practice problems really helped to clarify the topic
I thought today's lecture was very clear. I appreciated the car demonstration, as well as the Top Hat questions. It helped me stay engaged and better understand the topics covered.
I could follow along easily in this lecture. One thing that could've used more explaining was the right hand rule top hat question.

Cross products and into vs out of screen.
It was unclear how much time we would have in our groups to answer the tophat questions.

 right hand method. I will never understand. The top hat question about that rule made no sense to me. 
 Drawing position, velocity, and acceleration graphs. I had trouble with this in high school and still do not fully understand it

 the derivation and explanation of formulas for acceleration and velocity could've been covered and used in examples more
 i was still a little confused about the position velocity and acceleration graphs. i always get confused when interpreting them. i'll definitely go watch some youtube videos about it but it would go a little more in depth

 direction of result when using cross product

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the 2D application**: Specify that students had difficulty visualizing the Right-Hand Rule on a 2D graph and determining when it would be considered left-handed. This will help focus the improvement on this specific aspect.

2. **Emphasize positive/negative directions**: Highlight that students struggled with understanding how to determine if the result of a cross or dot product is positive or negative, and how this relates to the Right-Hand Rule. This will help target this particular confusion.

3. **Provide more practical examples**: Suggest offering additional practical examples, especially those involving 2D graphs and determining positive/negative directions. This will help address the specific challenges students faced, rather than a general call for more examples.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on the Right-Hand Rule generally clear, but several struggled with its application, particularly in 2D graphs and determining positive/negative directions. Many appreciated practical examples and interactive activities like Top Hat questions, but some found the rule's application confusing, especially when visualizing it on a 2D graph and understanding when it would be considered left-handed. Students also expressed difficulty in determining if the result of a cross or dot product is positive or negative, and how this relates to the Right-Hand Rule. To address these specific challenges, offering additional practical examples, especially those involving 2D graphs and determining positive/negative directions, would be beneficial.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify Specific Confusing Questions**: Instead of mentioning "notably the third question," list the specific TopHat questions that caused confusion, as mentioned by students (e.g., "Question 3 regarding the negative result, and the right-hand rule question").

Going in depth for more problems in class

Perhaps use a simple diagram or a real-world analogy to illustrate the positive and negative directions for each object in a relative motion scenario.

2. **Provide a clear guide for selecting kinematic equations**: Instead of just mentioning that students found it difficult to choose the right kinematic formula, suggest creating a decision tree or a step-by-step guide for selecting the appropriate equation based on the given information. This could help students understand the logic behind choosing one equation over another.

3. **Simplify the explanation of acceleration in circular motion**: To address the confusion around circular motion and acceleration, consider breaking down the explanation into simpler parts. For instance, first explain the concept of tangential acceleration, then introduce radial acceleration, and finally, discuss how these two components combine to give the resultant acceleration in circular motion. Using diagrams or animations could also help clarify this concept.

**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students engaged with the lecture on relative/circular motion but faced challenges in specific areas. The dinosaur problem, involving multiple objects, was a significant source of confusion. Students struggled to determine the direction of accelerations for each dinosaur and how to set up the equations accordingly. To address this, dedicating more time to explaining the positive and negative directions for each object in relative motion, perhaps using diagrams or real-world analogies, would be beneficial.

Students also found it difficult to select the appropriate kinematic formula. To help with this, creating a decision tree or a step-by-step guide for choosing the correct equation based on given information could provide clarity and understanding.

Circular motion and acceleration were another area of confusion. Students had trouble grasping how acceleration works in circular motion and differentiating between average and instantaneous velocities. To simplify this, consider breaking down the explanation into smaller parts, such as first explaining tangential acceleration, then radial acceleration, and finally, how these components combine to give the resultant acceleration. Using diagrams or animations could also help clarify this concept.

Overall, students appreciated the clear explanations and examples provided in the lecture, and felt that they had a solid understanding of the material.

suggestion:
Suggestions:

1. **Clarify Specific Confusions**: Instead of generalizing that "some students struggled," specify the main confusions. For example, "Students found it challenging to determine when to use sine or cosine (e.g., 'Just a quick review of when to use sin vs cos...') and when to add or subtract vectors (e.g., 'I was confused about when to add or subtract vectors...')."

2. **Highlight Key Topics**: Instead of listing all topics discussed, focus on the most challenging ones. For instance, "The lecture covered vector math, with a particular focus on the use of sine and cosine, vector subtraction, and unit vectors, which proved to be the most challenging topics for students."

3. **Avoid Repetition**: Instead of repeating that students found the lecture clear and easy to follow, mention it once and then focus on the areas of confusion. For example, "Students appreciated the clear explanations and examples, but found the following aspects challenging..."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the Vector Math lecture clear and engaging, with a few key areas of confusion. The main topics covered were the application of sine and cosine in vector math, vector subtraction, and unit vectors. Students struggled to determine when to use sine or cosine, especially in the context of word problems (e.g., "Just a quick review of when to use sin vs cos..."). Vector subtraction also posed challenges, particularly when deciding whether to add or subtract vectors (e.g., "I was confused about when to add or subtract vectors..."). Unit vectors were another source of confusion, with students seeking more context and explanation (e.g., "I am slightly confused about Unit Vectors..."). Despite these challenges, students appreciated the detailed explanations and examples provided, and felt they had a solid foundation in vector math. They also suggested more practice problems and examples to solidify their understanding.

 didn't have much trouble with any of the concepts presented in the lecture today. I have taken physics so this was a pretty basic review
 There honestly wasn't anything that was notably confusing or lacking in detail. (We're also working on vector basics in Calc 3 though, so it's possible that there was simply a lot of fortuitous overlap.)
 Today's video was good. I was confused throughout the video on how to know whether or not to subtract or add vectors based on the specific question, but I believe that is more so me understanding the problem and how to properly draw out the graph and vectors and understanding what the question is asking us to do than the actual math itself. Therefore I believe that with additional lectures and practice I will have it down!
 Most everything was described clearly, including teaching style, content, and Canvas. For me personally, I still had questions by the end of the lecture about what/how to use Piazza, TopHat, and Sapling. Luckily, everything was figured out by our second meeting through your clarification and other students help. 
 How the direction of a resultant vector compares to the value. I have trouble understanding their relationship.
 This was the first class with introductions and an overview of the course. I think my professor did a great job of explaining the course criteria and the websites we will be using throughout the semester.
 The only thing I found confusing in today's lecture was the second top hat question we did. I was confused about how to determine whether we would add the vectors or subtract them. 
 There was nothing confusing to me in today's lecture.
 The first multiple choice question confused me today. I was not sure how to do it or where to start but after the explanation I understand why the answer was B. 
 I was a little confused about the way tophat worked at the beginning of the lecture and how much time we would have for each part but after I used it for the first question I got the hang of it. 
 Everything was explained very well and in detail. I used law of sines and cosines for some problems but that's just cause I prefer it that way. 
 The only new thing to me was the idea of subtracting vectors. For example the top hat question was asking if you would add or subtract/which way you would subtract. However, with examples I was able to understand. I did like the breakout groups and getting to discuss with classmates. I also wish that the comment section was geared more towards questions and not comments because questions can get lost. Thanks.
 How, even with having to visualizing a resultant vector, the two addition vectors do not need to be visualized tip to tail.
 I thought today's lecture was good. One thing I'd like clarification on is vector notation if it hasn't already been specified in the question. Will you expect a specific notion? Will you expect the (i, j, k) notation or is arrow(<x,y>) acceptable too? 
 Our first lecture was not co fusing. We talked about the syllabus, how grading works, how extra credit is assigned, and what programs to install. The only confusing part is making sure we have all the software and books we need. Something that could help with that is a checklist.
 I had a bit of trouble interacting with others in the breakout rooms, but that is something I will work on improving myself. 
 I just don't understand when we subtract and don't add. I understand why we have to subtract certain ways but when do we subtract? 
 It seemed like some people didn't quite know how Tophat was going to work, and missed out on partial question points by not submitting an answer. Maybe another quick recap of the program and grading policies before starting the first question would be useful.
 I am still having some difficulties adding and subtracting vectors geometrically which also goes along with making the vector drawings for word problems. 
 Using Top Hat/getting used to using Top Hat was a bit confusing and tough. I wasn't always sure when to submit answers, how much time I had, and I had some trouble getting out of the zoom window quickly and to the Top Hat one. I think the more practice I get with it though the better I'll get at it. 
 The video was good today, and the worked out examples helped. I personally wasn't as prepared as I needed to be for class because this is my first flipped class ever. I look foreword to improving this for next class though.
 Maybe some clarification on when it is necessary to add 180 degrees to the answer of some problems and specifically how to identify when to do that both before you answer the problem and after. 
 I followed along very well in today's lecture, but I wish I had a bit more practice before answering the TOPHAT questions. I watched/did the extra problems and videos in addition to the quiz.
 A thing that confused me this lecture was how to subtract vectors. Now when I say this I am talking about the beginning of class, by the end of class I was beginning to understand through techniques like the trace method.
 Need more description about how you know what directions you draw vectors in all different cases, especially when you are trying to find the expression for a resultant using the subtraction of two other vectors. When drawing the resultant, do you always start from the first vector you drew and connect it to the last? I am very confused and others in my breakout room were too. 
 I am slightly confused about Unit Vectors. It would have been nice to have a bit more context or explanation about this topic. 
 I think it was a pretty good class, vector subtraction was a bit confusing but I think the explanation on adding vectors was great!
 In today's video lecture I struggled with figuring out when to subtract and when to add vectors. For example, in the yeti problem I did not know if you were supposed to add the two vectors or subtract them. The same goes for the Top Hat question earlier. in class regarding RA and RB. My instinct is to always add it it confuses me on when to subtract.
 Nothing from this video lecture was particularly unclear. It would be helpful to have more problems where unit vectors are used and/or examples of their overall use in physics. 
 Just needed back in the swing of all the trig functions. Haven't used them too much in about a year. 
 everything made sense, I didn't find anything confusing
 I have difficulty figuring out which direction (as in North of East or South of West) the resulting vector is pointing.

 Something that was confusing about today's video lecture was how in some cases with inverse tangent, you must add 180 degrees to your answer.  The lecture was overall very clear. The only part I found slightly confusing was the unit vectors, specially the purpose they serve, since it is just multiplying by 1.
 The video lectures were thorough about how to do the math for vectors. The thing that is confusing was the identification of scalars and vectors specifically if scalars need units or not.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) to various problems, such as pulley systems and the three-block problem, engaging and thought-provoking. They appreciated the "recipe" for drawing FBDs, which made the process easier. The concept of forces having resisting components and the ability to change the system analyzed to simplify calculations were particularly intriguing. Students also enjoyed the practical aspects, like how pulleys halve the force required to lift an object and the use of FBDs in the Atwood machine problem. They valued the interactive Top Hat questions and breakout room problems for reinforcing their understanding.
input:
The different applications of FBD to solve problems like the example of the man supporting himself on the pulley system. 
We had one of the same problems with two people pulling a rope on each side and the tension in the rope is between both of their forces
Despite this being a difficult concept, i though the man pulling himself up with a pulley was very interesting, as it shows how pulleys can be utilized in industry 
top hat
I found the fact that forces had resisting components interesting. 
drawing free body diagrams to set up equations
I found the fact that it became 2T interesting when he pulled himself up.
The “recipe” for free body diagrams. It made drawing them a lot easier.
I found it most interesting that to hold yourself still while on a pulley system, you only need to apply the force of half your weight. 
Today, I found the conceptual problem with the man pulling up with a velocity the most interesting. If you had done the problem in your mind, then you would have gotten twice the answer. 
 The pulley system/elevator problems because I find them very fun to do.
 I found the top hat questions about normal force to be most interesting 
 Top hat question where the man on the chair pulls on the rope. I thought it was an interesting real life problem to solve.
 The part that I found most interesting about today's lecture was the conceptual questions because they were tricky.
 I found the first example with the man in the chair the most interesting.  The fact that he only has to pull with half the force of gravity was intriguing. 
 free body diagrams

 the use of free bodies to solve the atwood machine problem with forces

2. **Highlight Key Concepts**: Emphasize the core understanding students gained from the topic, such as the importance of consistent direction choices in FBDs and the ability to redefine systems to simplify calculations.

refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students engaged with Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) through diverse problems like pulley systems, the three-block problem, and the ice block challenge. They appreciated the structured approach to drawing FBDs and the flexibility in choosing coordinate directions. Key concepts mastered included forces with resisting components, the ability to redefine systems for simpler calculations, and the practical application of pulleys in reducing lifting forces. Students found interactive Top Hat questions and collaborative breakout room problems particularly engaging, reinforcing their understanding of FBDs.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) to pulley/elevator problems engaging and insightful. They appreciated learning how to simplify forces using pulleys, with many noting that only half the force of gravity is needed to lift oneself, making these problems "fun to do." The concept of tension, where two objects exert equal forces on a rope, fascinated students. They also found it interesting that changing the system analyzed or the coordinate system could simplify problem-solving. The interactive nature of the lecture, including group tests and breakout rooms, was well-received.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate repetitive phrases**: Instead of repeatedly mentioning "students found" or "students appreciated," use more concise language like "noted" or "found useful" to save space.

   *Example*: "Students found the 'recipe' for drawing FBDs useful" can be "Noted the 'recipe' for drawing FBDs."

2. **Combine related points**: Group similar reflections together to make the summary more concise.

   *Example*: Instead of separate points about pulleys, combine them: "Noted the unique properties of pulley systems, such as halving the required force for lifting and transforming external forces into internal ones."

3. **Focus on the core concept of redefining systems**: Highlight the key takeaway about changing the system analyzed to simplify calculations, as this is the core topic of "Redefining Systems."

   *Example*: "Emphasized the strategic value of redefining systems to simplify calculations, as noted in the pulley system and multi-object problems."

Most notably, students emphasized the strategic value of redefining systems to simplify calculations, as demonstrated in the pulley system and multi-object problems, highlighting the core concept of "Redefining Systems."

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of friction, particularly in scenarios involving multiple blocks or surfaces, challenging to grasp. The top hat questions, especially those involving stacked blocks and different coefficients of friction, caused confusion due to their complexity and the need for clear conceptual understanding. Some students struggled with determining the forces involved, rearranging equations, and identifying when to use specific friction formulas. A few also expressed uncertainty about the distinction between static and kinetic friction, and the purpose of the maximum static friction (fs_max). Students requested more practice problems, clear explanations of formulas, and detailed solutions to help solidify their understanding of friction.

3. **Emphasize the Need for More Practice**: Rather than mentioning 'more practice problems' in general, specify the types of practice problems students requested. This will give the instructor a clearer idea of what to provide.

   *Revised*: "Students requested more practice problems involving blocks on top of each other, with varying coefficients of friction and surfaces, to help them apply their understanding of friction in different scenarios."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the application of friction principles, particularly in scenarios involving multiple blocks or surfaces, challenging. They struggled to calculate the force needed to move one block on top of another, combine free body diagrams for multiple blocks, and discern between static and kinetic friction. Students requested more practice problems featuring blocks on top of each other with varying coefficients of friction and surfaces to solidify their understanding of friction in diverse situations.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) mostly clear, but several points caused confusion. The main challenges were understanding FBDs for systems with multiple objects (especially when one object slides on another), determining the correct forces to include, and rearranging equations. Some students struggled with the conceptual difference between push and pull forces. A few also sought clarification on the coefficient of friction, its units, and the difference between static and kinetic friction.

**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) mostly clear, but two specific points caused confusion. The primary challenges were:

1. **Creating FBDs for Complex Systems**: Students found it challenging to create FBDs for systems with multiple objects, particularly when one object slides on another. This included understanding how to combine forces from different objects and how to account for friction between them.

2. **Identifying Relevant Forces**: Determining the correct forces to include in FBDs was another area of confusion for students. This was evident in their struggles with problems involving blocks on top of each other and blocks sliding on surfaces.

Additionally, students sought clarification on the concept of the coefficient of friction, its units, and the distinction between static and kinetic friction.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Top Hat questions engaging and helpful in solidifying their understanding of concepts, particularly Newton's Laws and tension. The group work and breakout rooms were also enjoyed for problem-solving.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of centripetal force challenging and desired more clarification, particularly regarding why the acceleration vector points towards the center in circular motion. The derivation of equations and application of concepts, such as terminal velocity and drag force, also caused confusion. Some students struggled with understanding the role of different forces, like normal force and friction, in circular motion. Additionally, the transition between substances and the impact on terminal velocity was a point of uncertainty. Students requested more examples, in-depth explanations, and time spent on these topics to better grasp centripetal force and its applications.
input:
Centripetal force was confusing and we spent very little time on it
I need more clarification about why the acceleration vector points in toward the center. 
Circular motion, centripetal force, equations relating to circular motion
I thought the problem with the skydiver into the ocean was confusing because there were too many variables.
The last example problem we did with the string and mass. I thought we didn't spend as much time on it as I would've liked. 
I struggled with the idea of how each variable impacts the overall equation for the drag force.
The most confusing part of the lecture was determining the centripetal force. 
Circular force was a bit confusing when dealing with acceleration. 
I was a little confused by the application of acceleration at an instant when terminal velocity changes. However, your explanation cleared it up. The application of multiple g's tripped me up and I got the practice problem incorrect as I forgot a g. 
I thought the question on terminal velocity was confusing. I was confused on how to set up the equation so that all the unknown variables would end up cancelling.
 I think it was tough to conceptualize some of the drag force problems. Although it's not going to be a heavy focus for the exam, I would've liked to connect more drag force problems to conceptual ideas.
 I found the example problem where the guy hits the water very confusing because of dealing with two different  densities.

 How circular motion works, and how the forces interact.
 Circular motion and how objects move around the circle
 The problem where the person was hitting the water confused me... I thought that because they were entering the water then mg would no longer be acting on them and the only force acting would be drag force
 The explanation of deriving the equations was confusing because it moved very quickly.
 The terminal velocity question with the difference in air and water density was challenging to see at first. 
 I was confused on the units for drag force 
 Today's lesson was not unclear or confusing. The only thing that could have been explained more in depth is centripetal force.
 I am still unclear about terminal velocity and when it is used. 
 the lesson moved really fast for such a complicated topic. deriving the equations was confusing and there weren't enough examples or applications to understand the formulas
 i found the centripetal problems a little confusing today. i think I just would like to see it more. besides that it was good. 
 A hard thing to understand is when a terminal velocity begins and ends when entering or exiting different substances.
 The first example of the terminal velocity and the acceleration before the man contacts the water.

 How the drag coefficient density of air and water can be in the same equation simultaneously

 Normal force on the top of a hill

 The problem with sonic going around in a circle confused me because it i didn't understand why it wasn't gravity 
 Tension problems could use some more examples like like a ball on a string moving in a circular path what is theta if given length of string, mass, and r maybe.
 the difference between uniform and nonuniform circular motion
 Nothing was really confusing in today's lecture
 Drag force, in particular, knowing when to substitute

 I'm confused on how centripetal force isn't an actual force.
 the effect of density on the terminal velocity
 Some of the components of drag force are a little confusing because I'm not totally sure how they all affect the overall drag.
 I would like more details on combining circular motion with free body diagrams in three dimensions, and I would like to know how much we need to know about doing derivatives of various equations.

input:
Centripetal force was confusing and we spent very little time on it
I need more clarification about why the acceleration vector points in toward the center. 
Circular motion, centripetal force, equations relating to circular motion
I thought the problem with the skydiver into the ocean was confusing because there were too many variables.
The last example problem we did with the string and mass. I thought we didn't spend as much time on it as I would've liked. 
I struggled with the idea of how each variable impacts the overall equation for the drag force.
The most confusing part of the lecture was determining the centripetal force. 
Circular force was a bit confusing when dealing with acceleration. 
I was a little confused by the application of acceleration at an instant when terminal velocity changes. However, your explanation cleared it up. The application of multiple g's tripped me up and I got the practice problem incorrect as I forgot a g. 
I thought the question on terminal velocity was confusing. I was confused on how to set up the equation so that all the unknown variables would end up cancelling.
 I think it was tough to conceptualize some of the drag force problems. Although it's not going to be a heavy focus for the exam, I would've liked to connect more drag force problems to conceptual ideas.
 I found the example problem where the guy hits the water very confusing because of dealing with two different  densities. 
 What was confusing about this lecture was what forces can be considered a centripetal force.  I saw that soletimes it can be the normal force or some other force.
 Circular motion/centripetal force caused by friction
 The example involving the acceleration and drag force on the jumper in the ocean.
 How circular motion works, and how the forces interact.
 Circular motion and how objects move around the circle
 The problem where the person was hitting the water confused me... I thought that because they were entering the water then mg would no longer be acting on them and the only force acting would be drag force
 The explanation of deriving the equations was confusing because it moved very quickly.
 The terminal velocity question with the difference in air and water density was challenging to see at first. 
 I was confused on the units for drag force 
 Today's lesson was not unclear or confusing. The only thing that could have been explained more in depth is centripetal force.
 I am still unclear about terminal velocity and when it is used. 
 the lesson moved really fast for such a complicated topic. deriving the equations was confusing and there weren't enough examples or applications to understand the formulas
 i found the centripetal problems a little confusing today. i think I just would like to see it more. besides that it was good. 
 A hard thing to understand is when a terminal velocity begins and ends when entering or exiting different substances.
 The first example of the terminal velocity and the acceleration before the man contacts the water.
 I felt that the first group problem was confusing but once we went over it I understood it better 
 I don't get how velocity changes when you switch between materials.
 Not too confused, just a bit worried about the exam next week.
 How the drag coefficient density of air and water can be in the same equation simultaneously 
 circular motion was barely even taught, especially the net force portion 
 On the first top hat group question finding the equation and what cancelled out 
 I think more explanation should be there for the top hat examples. I was confused at a few steps.
 Normal force on the top of a hill
 I thought the last two top hat questions were confusing 
 Trying to solve a problem with very to no numbers given and having to figure out the algebra and forces 
 The problem with sonic going around in a circle confused me because it i didn't understand why it wasn't gravity 
 Tension problems could use some more examples like like a ball on a string moving in a circular path what is theta if given length of string, mass, and r maybe.
 the difference between uniform and nonuniform circular motion
 Nothing was really confusing in today's lecture
 Drag force, in particular, knowing when to substitute
 Figuring out how to do the pendulum because the wording of the question didn't make it obvious to me
 I'm confused on how centripetal force isn't an actual force.
 the effect of density on the terminal velocity
 Some of the components of drag force are a little confusing because I'm not totally sure how they all affect the overall drag.
 I would like more details on combining circular motion with free body diagrams in three dimensions, and I would like to know how much we need to know about doing derivatives of various equations.

2. **Distinguish Between Centripetal Force and Other Forces**: To address the confusion about what forces can be considered centripetal, revise the summary to emphasize that students had difficulty differentiating between centripetal force and other forces (like normal, friction, or tension) that might be present in circular motion scenarios.
